Label: No Poverty
Description: End poverty in all its forms everywhere

Label: Zero Hunger
Description: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture

Label: Good Health and Well-Being
Description: Ensure healthy lives and promote wellbeing for all at all ages

Label: Quality Education
Description: Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all

Label: Gender Equality
Description: Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls

Label: Clean Water and Sanitation
Description: Ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all

Label: Affordable and Clean Energy
Description: Ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all

Label: Decent Work and Economic Growth
Description: Promote sustained, inclusive and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment, and decent work for all

Label: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure
Description: Build resilient infrastructure, promote inclusive and sustainable industrialisation, and foster innovation

Label: Reduced Inequalities
Description: Reduce inequality within and among countries

Label: Sustainable Cities and Communities
Description: Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable

Label: Responsible Consumption and Production
Description: Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns

Label: Climate Action
Description: Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts (taking note of agreements made by the UNFCCC forum)

Label: Life Below Water
Description: Conserve and sustainably use the oceans, seas and marine resources for sustainable development

Label: Life on Land
Description: Protect, restore and promote sustainable use of terrestrial ecosystems, sustainably manage forests, combat desertification and halt and reverse land degradation, and halt biodiversity loss

Label: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
Description: Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels

Label: Partnerships for the Goals
Description: Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalise the global partnership for sustainable development

Label: Tropical and Subtropical Dry and Humid Forests
Description: *Main description: Includes humid and dry broadleaf forests centered between the tropics and at subtropical latitudes, and tropical and subtropical coniferous forests. Humid forests are characterized by low variability in annual temperature and high levels of rainfall (>2000 mm annually); forest composition is dominated by evergreen and semi-evergreen tree species. Dry forests occur in climates that are mostly warm year-round, with annual rainfall ranging from 200 to 1500 mm. There is a well-defined dry season which can last several months and vary with geographic location. Semi-deciduous and deciduous trees predominate in these forests. Tropical and subtropical coniferous forests are found predominantly in North and Central America. They experience low levels of precipitation and moderate variability in temperature. They are characterized by diverse species of conifers, whose needles are adapted to deal with the variable climatic conditions.

Label: Temperate and Boreal Forests and Woodlands
Description: ...pending

Label: Mediterranean Forests, Woodlands and Scrub
Description: *Main description: Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub ecoregions are characterized by hot and dry summers, while winters tend to be cool and moist. Most precipitation arrives during these months. Although the habitat is globally rare, it features an extraordinary biodiversity of uniquely adapted animal and plant species, which can adapt to the stressful conditions of long, hot summers with little rain. Most plants are fire adapted, and dependent on this disturbance for their persistence. The Mediterranean unit of analysis is discontinuous, spread across five continents and 22 countries: Europe and Africa in the Mediterranean Basin, the western United States (California) and Mexico (northwest Baja), South America in central Chile, the cape region of South Africa, and south and southwestern Australia

Label: Tundra and High Mountain Habitats
Description:
*Main description: the tundra comprises the vast, nearly level, treeless plains of the arctic regions of Europe, Asia, and North America. It consists of a black mucky soil with a permanently frozen subsoil (permafrost), and has a dominant vegetation of mosses, lichens, herbs, and dwarf shrubs. This unit also includes high mountainous areas above the timber line. However, high mountains are not precisely defined, and for purposes of this Unit, they are defined as mountains greater than 2000 m altitude and above.
*Other UoAs: this unit is distinguished from the cryosphere as being characterized by vegetation cover.

Label: Tropical and Subtropical Savannas and Grasslands
Description:
*Main description: Tropical and Subtropical Grasslands and Savannas are characterized by rainfall levels between 300-1500 mm per year. However, there may be great variability in soil moisture throughout the year. In general, grasses dominate the species composition of these ecoregions, although scattered trees may be common. Large mammals that have evolved to take advantage of the ample forage typify the biodiversity associated with these habitats.
*Other UoAs: subtropical shrublands (which are included in Olson et al., 2001) are included in UoA7 (Deserts and Xeric shrublands). Some parts of these two units may overlap, as it is common for some areas of the subtropical savannas to be described as xerophytic shrublands.

Label: Temperate Grasslands
Description: *Main description: Temperate grasslands occur where seasonal climates and soils favour the dominance of perennial grasses and related life forms. They are distributed mainly in the middle latitudes with differing names across continents. Steppes, prairies, pampas, and veld areas, but also including (semi-) natural (ancient or primary) grasslands and forest-steppes, wood-pastures, “temperate savannas” and open shrublands(?) in the regions of Temperate and Boreal broadleaved, mixed and coniferous forests, Mediterranean regions and of mountains below the timberline, excluding tundra grasslands, subtropical grasslands and savannas, deserts and xeric shrublands, and grasslands above the timberline, and also excluding intensively managed, improved agricultural grasslands.

Label: Deserts and Xeric Shrublands
Description: ...pending

Label: Wetlands (Peatlands, Mires, Bogs)
Description: *Main description: Wetlands are areas where water covers the soil, or is present either at or near the surface of the soil all year or for varying periods of time during the year. Water saturation by groundwater, precipitation, surface waters and ocean tides largely determines how frequently or continually the soil is inundated and develops and the types of plant and animal communities living in and on the soil. Includes natural and constructed permanent forest covered inland marshes and wet meadows (dominated by herbaceous plants), swamps (dominated by shrubs), wooded swamps (dominated by trees), seasonal freshwater wetlands (playa lakes, vernal pools, potholes, marshes), seawater and freshwater tidal swamps and marshes (linked to estuaries or beyond the upper edges of tidal salt marshes where the influence of salt water ends), and unforested mires such as bogs, fens and other peatlands.

Label: Urban/Semi-Urban
Description: *Main description: a formal description has not been made, but operationally, we have decided to use the urban land cover class from http://maps.elie.ucl.ac.be/CCI/viewer/. The definition is forthcoming.

Label: Cultivated Areas
Description: *Main description: Cultivated systems can be defined as areas in which at least 30% of the landscape is in croplands, shifting cultivation, confined livestock production, or freshwater aquaculture in any year

Label: Cryosphere
Description: *Main description: The cryosphere consists of regions where water exists primarily in a frozen state most of the time, i.e. the polar regions, glaciers and alpine regions. Contains many highly unique habitats / ecosystems such as sea ice, ice shelfs, areas with permafrost, the extreme cold and dry regions of the Antarctica including the Antarctic dry valleys and the sub-glacial/ice sheet lakes (ex. Lake Vostok).

Label: Aquaculture Areas
Description: *Main description: Aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms, including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Farming implies some form of intervention in the rearing process to enhance production, such as regular stocking, feeding, protection from predators, etc. Farming also implies individual or corporate ownership of the stock being cultivated. Aquatic organisms which are harvested by an individual or corporate body which has owned them throughout their rearing period contribute to aquaculture, while aquatic organisms which are exploitable as a common property resources, with or without appropriate licenses, are the harvest of fisheries. Aquaculture areas are thus any area of land, freshwater or marine water that is used in the production of cultured organisms.

Label: Inland Surface Waters and Water Bodies/Freshwater
Description: *Main description: Inland waters are permanent above-ground open fresh or brackish water bodies inland from the coastal zone and areas, including their littoral zones. Includes natural (lakes, rivers, streams, springs, water courses, deltas, inland saline systems, and bays nearest to the shore of a nation and are subject to its complete sovereignty) and constructed (reservoirs, ponds, pools) permanent water bodies which support a natural community of both plants and animals. Littoral zones include those parts of banks or shores that are sufficiently frequently inundated to prevent the formation of closed terrestrial vegetation

Label: Shelf Ecosystems (Neritic and Intertidal/Littoral Zone)
Description:
*Main description: In-shore pelagic and benthic systems extending from the coastline to the 200m depth contour. At the coastal boundary, includes the intertidal/littoral zone to the Mean High Tide Water Line including estuaries to their inner boundary (approx. 5%o, see Wolanski 2007).
*Other UoAs: borders on the open ocean (UoA15) at its outer boundary and may (see*Additional notes/inclusions) touch on the deep ocean (UoA16) in some locations; inshore regions with permanent ice are placed in the cryosphere (UOA11), floating above, or beside, UoA14; freshwater coastal rivers/lakes (UoA13-Inland surface waters and water bodies/freshwater) may form a boundary with estuaries; shelf systems intensively/multiply used by man are separated from this unit into “Hotspots of endemic species” section.
*Additional notes/exceptions/inclusions:
- Inner-shelf depressions (over deepened basins) can be deeper but belong to the shelf (canyons being open to the deep-sea belong to UoA 16). 
- depth may extend to <500 m around Antarctica and Antarctic islands close to the continent, no Sub-Antarctic islands 
- Sub-units of analysis: a) mangrove forests are included as they are in the littoral zone and estuaries (Olds et al 2015, UNEP_WCMC mangrove layer) b) seagrass meadows (Orth et al 2006, UNEP_WCMC seagrass layer) c) tidal flats & salt marshes are in the littoral zone/estuaries (Orth et al 2006, UNEP_WCMC saltmarsh layer) d) rocky and sandy shores incl. tide pools, are in the littoral zone. e) kelp forests (Steneck et al. 2002), f) coral and other biogenic reefs (UNEP_WCMC coral reef layer) g) soft and poorly sorted bottoms incl. over deepened troughs with overlying water body. h) deltas and estuaries - high in population

Label: Open Ocean Pelagic Systems (Euphotic Zone)
Description:
*Main description:Upper light-flooded (euphotic) layer of the off-shore open ocean beyond the 200-m depth contour on the seabed (beyond 500m in Antarctica), where phytoplankton grow (=Net Primary Production). Its lower limit is the compensation depth roughly at 200m water depth (for scientific definition see e.g. Kaiser et al. 2005).
*Other UoAs:Open ocean pelagic systems (UoA 15) gradually turns to the dark pelagic zones (UoA 16) below and is linked to the deep sea-floor by biogeochemical pelagic-benthic coupling and vertical migration of organisms. The cryosphere (UoA 11) includes ice shelves, but the sea below or adjacent to them falls into UoA15 or UoA16 (according to depth). Also the boundary between upper light-flooded (euphotic) layer of the off-shore open ocean (UoA 15) and the shelf ecosystems (UoA 14) represents gradients in various ecologically relevant environmental parameters rather than discrete transitions.
*Additional notes/exceptions/inclusions:
- Sub-units of analysis: a) central oceanic gyres incl. Sargasso Sea and Antarctic Circumpolar Current (Longhurst 1998), b) High-Nutrient, Low-Chlorophyll systems (World Ocean Assessment 2016, World Ocean Atlas 2009, 2013, SeaWiFS), c) cold ice-covered polar seas (Orsi et al 1995, International Hydrographic Organization 2001), d) upwelling systems including predominantly pelagic Oxygen Minimum Zones, both partly also occur on shelves (UoA 14) and affect the deep sea-floor (UoA 16); Easter Boundary Upwelling: Gómez-Gesteira et al (2008), Capone & Hutchins (2013), equatorial upwelling and at ocean frontal systems: http://www.marinebio.net/marinescience/02ocean/swmovement.htm, http://www.seos-project.eu/modules/oceancurrents/oceancurrents-c04-p04.html, Gordon et al 1977) also in gyres.
- Sub-units of analysis can differ considerably in biodiversity and ecosystem functioning but also partially overlap.

Label: Deep Sea
Description:
*Main description: Dark off-shore open ocean beyond the 200m depth contour on the seabed (beyond 500m in Antarctica), and greater than 200m deep (500m in Antarctica), below the euphotic zone (UoA 15), including the sea-floor and the dark pelagic zones (e.g. Seibold & Berger 1996, Gage & Tyler 1992, Kaiser et al. 2005, Ramirez-Llodra et al. 2010, Harris et al. 2014).
Boundary between UoA 15 and UoA 16 at approx. 200m is of significant ecological but low physiological relevance since species are specifically adapted to pressure (http://www.marinespecies.org/deepsea/). These two layers are directly linked through pelagic-benthic biogeochemical coupling and vertical migration of pelagic organisms. The cryosphere (UoA 11) includes ice shelves, but the sea below or adjacent to them falls into UoA15 or UoA16 (according to depth).
*Additional notes/exceptions/inclusions:
- Sub-units of analysis: a) slope and rise of continents and islands incl. canyons, 200-2000m and 2000 - 4000m along continents, respectively b) abyssal plains (4000 - 6000m sounding depth) including mid-ocean ridges (usually: 5000-2500m sounding depth; https://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/dynamic/baseball.html https://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/image/crustageposter.gif and Gubbins 2008, according to crust age. Sub-UoA 16e overlaps with shelf ecosystems (UoA 14), where mid-ocean ridges hit continents. c) vents and seeps (German et al. 2011; rarely also on shelves: UoA 14), d) seamounts (Clark et al. 2010, 2011), e) cold coral reefs (World Ocean Assessment 2016, Freiwald et al. 2004, Roberts et al. 2010; also on shelves: UoA 14 and 17, f) deep-sea trenches (8-45° slopes, 6000 - 11000m sounding depth) g) dark (aphotic) pelagic zone, incl. meso- (20-1000m), bathy (1000-4000m), abyss (4000-6000m), and hado- (6000-11000m) pelagic zones (Kaiser et al. 2005).
- Sub-Units a-f include the bottom-near pelagial (nepheloid layer) and its sub-unit specific processes.

Label: Coastal Areas Intensively and Multiply Used By Human
Description:
*Main description: This Unit of Analysis is restricted to artificial constructions on the coastline and in coastal waters, focused on physical rather than biological function and attributes. It includes: a) Coastal Defense Schemes: Breakwaters, Groynes and Jetties; b) Coastal Erosion Schemes: Seawalls, Bulkheads; c) infrastructure protection schemes: Pilings; d) Floating docks to create boating facilities; e) artificial islands; f) dumping and mining areas; and g) port development and coastal support facilities (as required by four types of activities: 1) offshore oil and gas development requires port facilities, oil storage capacity, refineries and other infrastructure support; 2) the shipping industry requires channels, port facilities, shipyards and extensive land areas for container storage; 3) fisheries development requires breakwaters, channels, ports, processing plants and other facilities for the fishing fleet; and 4) military operations will require port facilities, infrastructure, and support services).
*Other UoAs:heavily altered and multiply used areas that are focused on biological function for aquaculture are included in UOA 12, Aquaculture areas. There may be some difficulty in separating this UOA from UOA 9, Urban/semi-urban, as many of the structures defined here will be contiguous with UOA9.*Additional notes/exceptions/inclusions: Currently, 2.5 billion people (40% of the world’s population) live within 100 km of the coast, adding increased pressure to coastal areas. The term coastal zone means the coastal waters (including the lands therein and thereunder) and the adjacent shore lands (including the waters therein and thereunder), in proximity to the shorelines of the land includes islands, transitional and inter-tidal areas, salt marshes, wetlands, and beaches (NOAA). The coastal zone is used extensively for a large number of human activities. The shoreline boundary is used for human settlement, agriculture, trade, industry and amenity. The coastal sea is intensively used for transport, fishing, dumping, mining, etc., stemming from an intensification and diversification of ocean uses. There is overexploitation of fishery resources as well as pollution by dumping (Clark, 1991c). Coastal zones are the “sink” for the continents; they receive and concentrate pollutants and other negative consequences of development activities taking place in the hinterlands. Coastal development linked to human settlements, industry, aquaculture, or infrastructure causes severe impacts on coastal areas.

Label: Habitat creation and maintenance
Description: The formation and continued production, by ecosystems or organisms within them, of ecological conditions necessary or favourable for organisms important to humans. E.g. nesting, feeding, and mating sites for birds and mammals, resting and overwintering areas for migratory mammals, birds and butterflies, nurseries for juvenile stages of fish

Label: Pollination and seed dispersal
Description: Facilitation by animals of movement of pollen among flowers, and dispersal of seeds, larvae or spores of organisms important to humans

Label: Regulation of air quality
Description:
Regulation (by impediment or facilitation) by ecosystems, of CO2/O2 balance, O3 for UV-B absorption, levels of sulphur oxide, nitrogen oxides (NOx), volatile organic compounds (VOC), particulates, aerosols. 
Filtration, fixation, degradation or storage of pollutants that directly affect human health or infrastructure

Label: Regulation of climate
Description:
Climate regulation by ecosystems (including regulation of global warming) through:
* Positive or negative effects on emissions of greenhouse gases (e.g. biological carbon storage and sequestration; methane emissions from wetlands)
* Positive or negative effects on biophysical feedbacks from vegetation cover to atmosphere, such as those involving albedo, surface roughness, long-wave radiation, evapotranspiration (includingmoisture-recycling)
* Direct and indirect processes involving biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC)
* Regulation of aerosols and aerosol precursors

Label: Regulation of ocean acidification
Description: Regulating, by photosynthetic organisms (on land or in water), of atmospheric CO2 concentrations and so seawater pH, which affects associated calcification processes by many marine organisms important to humans (such as corals)

Label: Regulation of freshwater quantity, flow and timing
Description:
Regulation, by ecosystems, of the quantity, location and timing of the flow of surface and groundwater used for drinking, irrigation, transport, hydropower, and as the support of non-material contributions (NCP 15, 16, 17)
Regulation of flow to water-dependent natural habitats that in turn positively or negatively affect people downstream, including via flooding (wetlands including ponds, rivers, lakes, swamps)
Modifying groundwater levels, which can ameliorate dryland salinization in unirrigated landscapes

Label: Regulation of freshwater and coastal water quality
Description: Regulation – through filtration of particles, pathogens, excess nutrients, and other chemicals – by ecosystems or particular organisms, of the quality of water used directly (e.g. drinking) or indirectly (e.g. aquatic foods, irrigated food and fibre crops, freshwater and coastal habitats of heritage value)

Label: Formation, protection and decontamination of soils
Description: Sediment retention and erosion control, soil formation and maintenance of soil structure and processes (e.g. such as decomposition and nutrient cycling) that underlie the continued fertility of soils important to humans. Filtration, fixation, degradation or storage of chemical and biological pollutants (pathogens, toxics, excess nutrients) in soils and sediments that are important to humans

Label: Regulation of hazards and extreme events
Description:
Amelioration, by ecosystems, of the impacts on humans or their infrastructure caused by e.g. floods, wind, storms, hurricanes, seawater intrusion, tidal waves, heat waves, tsunamis, high noise levels
Reduction, by ecosystems of hazards like landslides, avalanches

Label: Regulation of organisms detrimental to humans
Description:
Regulation, by ecosystems or organisms, of pests, pathogens, predators, competitors, etc. that affect humans, plants and animals, including e.g.:
* Regulation by predators or parasites of the population size of non-harmful important animals (e.g. large herbivore populations by wolves or lions)
* Regulation (by impediment or facilitation) of the abundance or distribution of potentially harmful organisms (e.g. venomous, toxic, allergenic, predators, parasites, competitors, disease vectors and reservoirs) over the landscape or seascape
* Removal of animal carcasses and human corpses by scavengers (e.g. vultures in Zoroastrian and some Tibetan Buddhist traditions)
* Regulation (by impediment or facilitation) of biological impairment and degradation of infrastructure (e.g. damage by pigeons, bats, termites, strangling figs to buildings)

Label: Energy
Description: Production of biomass-based fuels, such as biofuel crops, animal waste, fuelwood, agricultural residue pellets

Label: Food and feed
Description:
Production of food from wild, managed, or domesticated organisms, such as fish, beef, poultry, game, dairy products, edible crops, mushrooms, bushmeat and edible invertebrates, honey, edible wild fruits and tubers
Production of feed for domesticated animals (e.g. livestock, work and support animals, pets) or for aquaculture, from the same sources

Label: Materials and assistance
Description:
Production of materials derived from organisms in crops or wild ecosystems, for construction, clothing, printing, ornamental purposes (e.g. wood, fibres, waxes, paper, resins, dyes, pearls, shells, coral branches).
Direct use of living organisms for decoration (i.e. ornamental plants in parks and households, ornamental fish), company (i.e. pets),transport, and labor (including herding, searching, guidance, guarding)

Label: Medicinal, biochemical and genetic resources
Description:
Production of materials derived from organisms (plants, animals, fungi, microbes) used for medicinal and veterinary purposes
Production of genes and genetic information used for plant and animal breeding and biotechnology

Label: Learning and inspiration
Description: Provision, by landscapes, seascapes, habitats or organisms, of opportunities for the development of the capabilitiesthat allow humans to prosper through education, acquisition of knowledge and development of skills for well-being, scientific information, and inspiration for art and technological design (e.g. biomimicry)

Label: Physical and psychological experiences
Description: Provision, by landscapes, seascapes, habitats or organisms, of opportunities for physically and psychologically beneficial activities, healing, relaxation, recreation, leisure, tourism and aesthetic enjoyment based on the close contact with nature. E.g. hiking, recreational hunting and fishing, birdwatching, snorkeling, gardening

Label: Supporting identities
Description:
Landscapes, seascapes, habitats or organisms being the basis for religious, spiritual, and social-cohesion experiences
Provisioning of opportunities by nature for people to develop a sense of place, purpose, belonging, rootedness or connectedness, associated with different entities of the living world (e. g. cultural and heritage landscapes, sounds, scents and sights associated with childhood experiences, iconic animals, trees or flowers)
Basis for narratives and myths, rituals and celebrations provided by landscapes, seascapes, habitats, species or organisms (e.g. sacred groves, sacred trees, totem animals)
Source of satisfaction derived from knowing that a particular landscapes, seascape, habitat or species exist in the present

Label: Maintenance of options
Description:
Capacity of ecosystems, habitats, species or genotypes to keep human options open in order to support a later good quality of life. Examples include:
* Benefits (including those of future generations) associated with the continued existence of a wide variety of species, populations and genotypes
* Future benefits (or threats) derived from keeping options open for yet unknown discoveries and unanticipated uses of particular organisms or ecosystems that already exist (e.g. new medicines or materials)
* Future benefits (or threats) that may be anticipated from on-going biological evolution (e.g. adaptation to a warmer climate, to emergent diseases, development of resistance to antibiotics and other control agents by pathogens and weeds)

Label: Climate: Global Temperature
Description: Increasing global average temperatures and their local/regional modification

Label: Climate: Greenhouse Gas Concentrations
Description:
Increasing atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases, in particular CO2, and their direct consequences, such as for instance: 
• sea level rise, 
• ocean acidification, 
• changing temperature and precipitation patterns, 
• destabilisation of weather patterns and 
• changes in the frequency and strength of extreme weather events

Label: Pollution (The Level Of ~)
Description:
Contamination or undesirable modification of soil, water, the atmosphere, food or living space by a noxious or toxic substance, noise or light. Pollution comprises
• deliberate emissions into an ecosystem such as surplus amounts of agrochemicals into gardens and agro-ecosystems, or de-icing products on roads, affecting soil, ground water and biodiversity,
• spill-over of substances from the target ecosystem (where they may be harmless or useful) to sensitive ecosystems (e.g. run-off from adjacent land areas into limnic or marine ecosystems),
• disposal or deposition of effluents, e.g. industrial pollution of soil, water or air (other than emission of greenhouse gases) or garbage disposal.

Label: Land Use Changes (The Intensity Of ~)
Invasive Alien Species (The Number Of ~)
Description:
Alterations in the large scale distribution of organisms 
• purposeful introduction of organisms, including those considered invasive (e.g. for leisure or decorational purposes)
• unintentional introduction of species and varieties, including those considered invasive (e.g. dispersion by global trade)
• spread of zoonoses, pathogens, agents of disease

Label: Economic (The Intensity Of ~ Processes)
Description: All processes of extraction, processing, manufacturing, distributing, transferring (money, investment), exchanging (trade), consuming and disposing goods and services affecting human individuals, social entities and nature, nature’s benefits to people and good quality of life

Label: Demographic (Human Population Size)
Description: The population development of humans, including changes of population size and age structure. Relevant parameters for a given population include growth rate, fertility rate, mortality rate, replacement rate; for the overall population development they have to be combined with data on migration patterns and flows (e.g., internal migration, displacement, urbanization trends)

Label: Technological (The Rate Of New ~ Innovations)
Description: Technological innovations, i.e. the application of inventions (discoveries and new insights or paradigms) which can have both positive and negative effects on nature, nature’s contributions to people and a good quality of life

Label: Governance (The Prevalence Of Participatory ~ Processes)
Description: Formal or informal, multi-stakeholder processes impacting the status quo of societies/communities and the ways in which power and decisions are allocated among their members, affecting nature, nature’s benefits to people and good quality of life.

Label: Cultural (The Rate Of ~ Changes)
Description: Cultural drivers include but are not limited to prevailing or changing habits, routines, consumption patterns, behavioural norms, rituals and belief systems shaping humans’ attitude to and interaction with nature, affecting nature’s benefits to people and good quality of life

Label: Health Problems (The Number & Severity Of ~)
Description: Larger-scale epidemics (pandemics), as well as wide-spread (endemic) diseases affecting the good quality of life

Label: Regional Conflicts, Wars (The Number & Severity Of ~)
Description: While the motivations of agents vary (e.g. resource control, political control, territorial enclosure, regime change), civil conflicts most often begin with the exclusion of social groups by majorities or power holders, denying them, amongst other rights, access to infrastructure and public services (water, energy, sewage, garbage collection). Such conflicts can escalate into violence by suppression or by resistance, or both, resulting in severe social and environmental impacts, human suffering and conflict-driven migration. When conflicts turn violent, nature (in the vast majority of cases) and humans suffer alike: war is the ultimate unsustainability. Nature, nature’s benefits to people and good quality of life tend to suffer significantly in both cases.

Label: Production Patterns (The Degree Of "Globalistaion")
Description: Patterns of production comprise the kinds of products produced and the means (technologies, work organisation, resources used incl. energy) of doing so. Patterns of supply refer to the sourcing of inputs, local vs. global, and the kind of supply chains involved. Patterns of consumption comprise both the level of consumption and the composition of consumption.
